title: Get Out Film Review
review:
An interracial college couple, Chris and Rose, set out to meet Rose's family. Chris an African American, is apprehensive of meeting Rose's family because he is black and sadly, not many white people are accepting of interracial relationship. While at Rose's family's house, Chris experiences an uncomfortable welcome from a family who seemingly is very accepting of the situation. Chris interacts with the family's two black housekeepers, Walter and Georgina. From the moment we meet Walter and Georgina, we can tell something isn't right and they appear to be in some sort of trance, or zombie-like state, but function completely normal. Rose's family holds their annual get together with other people, predominately white, in their community. While Chris' discomfort rises, the family begins to show their true motives behind their community. Chris wants to leave, meanwhile, the community holds a secret auction to sell Chris' body to a member of the community. The goal of Rose's family is to hypnotize Chris so that Rose's father, who is a neurosurgeon, can implant the brain of another white person so that they can use Chris' body to their advantage. Chris manages to escape with the help of his close friend Rod. This film feels like The Stepford Wives with modern elements and modern issues that are addressed.
Get Out is a horror movie that gives satisfaction to those who love a good thrill and deep message for those who enjoy meaningful substance in the film. The theme for getting Out is a focus on ideas and more specifically, a focus on social problems and the truth of human nature. Get Out really hits on race and racism issues that people of color face in America today. Racism isn't always blatant, and, in this case, it comes from the least expected family. Rose comes from a middle-high class white liberal family, appearing to be accepting of her African American boyfriend Chris. However, there is a deeper motive for the Armitage family and their community. They use people of color to preserve the minds of fellow Caucasians by transplanting their brains into the bodies of black people. For some people like Hudson who wanted to use Chris's body because of his ability to see and his photography skills. Then there is Rose's family who use Georgina and Walter to preserve the minds of their family elderly family members and use them as modern-day servants.
Get Out is filled with symbolism that supports the theme of the film and helps tie the story together. When Rose's mother hypnotizes Chris, she refers to his hypnotic state as "the sunken place" and this symbolizes the treatment of people of color in America throughout history. Whether its slavery or mass incarceration, people of color have felt powerless and vulnerable just like Chris in the "sunken place" state.
For a satirical horror film, this really will put the audience on edge and that is the brilliant work of the editor, Gregory Plotkin. The key to a good horror film is not necessarily the content that is scary but the moments that make the audience "jump." The well-timed surprises like when Chris and Rose ran into a deer on the way to Rose's parent's house made for a jolting scene and could take away an audience members breath. The editor liked to build up suspense and make the audience feel like something was going to happen but then use time control to throw the audience off and have the suspenseful moment happen during the least expected times.
Jordan Peele, first time director, put together a wonderful piece of art that catches the essence of multiple themes, including focusing on the truth of human nature, social problems and wrapped together in a horror style package. This horror movie isn't a typical dark and twisted film, it is lighter and more suspenseful, but the evil actions of the characters are what make this film belong in the horror genre.

title: An Odd film to watch
review:
I quite enjoyed this film, with a racial slant, which was probably unnecessary, however the director is tapping in to the sad divisions in the west at the moment, which no doubt has boosted views and ratings.

The film is quite weird throughout, but enjoyable. It has been popping up in top rated horrors, when i am looking for a film to watch, which essentially drew me to the film. It in no way should be brought within a best horror film list, however as i said, the director played to the outrage crowd that will give it high ratings as they pander to the racial divisions of society.

The story throughout is intiguing and keeps you watching to the end. If you are not keen on classic films like videodrome, IT, white worms lair you will not enjoy this. I have done the hard work for you here and do not watch, as parts of the film annoy you(not as much as thise films though).

If you are a movie fan, you will want to see this, as many will have enjoyed it and I have to say, i did eventually, it was a bit of a struggle at early points. I have to say, the young fella Daniel Kaluuya is brilliant in the role and his friend Lil Rel Howery adds for some decent laughs regarding racial stereotypes.

I gave the film 7, therefore, give it a watch, but do not make it a priotity watch.

title: Wasn't bad
review: This movie was pretty predictable. Unique yes. Entertaining? Not really. I found myself dozing a few times in the theatre. For me this wasn't the masterpiece it claimed to be. I wouldn't watch it again but for a one time watch it was fine. But easy to forget right when you leave the theatre.

title: IMDb Movie Review
review:
In the horror and suspense film Get Out Chris Washington (Daniel Kaluuya) is taking the next step in his relationship with Rose Armitage (Allison Williams) and taking a weekend trip to meet her parents. Upon their arrival Chris meets Rose's parents Missy Armitage (Catherine Keener) and Dean Armitage (Bradley Whitford) and notices something off but thinks it's just their way of dealing with Rose's interracial relationship with Chris. Chris soon realizes he was wrong and as the weekend moves on things keep getting stranger and eventually leads to his bad thoughts becoming a reality turning his worst nightmare into a real-life experience.
The movie Get Out will keep you on the edge of your seat just when you thought you had it figured out a plot twist/plot point happens completely changing the direction of the film. When Chris is sitting down with the family and he finally gets to chat with Rose's brother Jeremy Armitage (Caleb Jones) you can see the movie take a big turn for the worst int this scene. The forcefulness that Jeremy shows towards Chris is a big turning point in the film and adds to the theme of the film by creating more suspense. Right after that scene the horror aspect comes into the film when Chris is outside trying to get air and gets spooked by Walter (Marcus Henderson) and returns inside the home to be startled by Missy Armitage. Missy Armitage proceeds to sit Chris down and tricks him into being hypnotized and this is when everything takes a turn for the worst. At this point in the film Chris knows something is not right he just can't put his finger on it. Things keep compiling through out the film leading up to his worst nightmare coming true when trying to leave the house with Rose. In this scene they tie the suspense and horror together by keeping Rose as an innocent person in the film and turning all the other family members against Chris. This doesn't last long as Rose breaks that innocent character identity and reveals her identity as a part of the dysfunctional crazy family. They then proceed to do what they had planned all along with Chris and begin the process of transferring Jim Hudson (Stephen Root) brain particles into Chris's head until at the last minute he figures out how to stop the situation and plans and successfully escapes the hell he had been living all weekend.
The movie Get Out did an awesome job with setting the stage for this film to be not only a suspenseful one but also a horror film. The lighting that they used in the film really helps give off that horror vibe while watching it. When something happens especially to Chris the lighting is always dark and dim making it hard to see anything. As you are trying to focus in on the scene something either pops up or happens making you jump or startled. Another technique they used to help give it that horror sense was the angle of the scenes being filmed. For instance, when Dean is cutting open Jim's head you can't see exactly what he is doing but you know it. Then the blood starts to drip onto the sheet that's separating us from the procedure and you get this gut wrenching feeling overwhelming you. If you have ever seen the movie Hostel you know exactly what I mean as it has the same story line of starting off as a great weekend trip and quickly turning into a complete nightmare. Using the same techniques to give you that suspense/horror feel to the movie. If you are into movie that have lots of plot twist and keep you on the edge of your seat I would highly recommend you see the movie Get Out!

title: Powerful, clever, poignant
review:
Get Out is an extremely powerful, poignant horror movie with some humor. Whatever elements of action or schlock that are present take a backseat to the real human drama that plays out when Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) meets his white girlfriend's eccentric family.

The characters are fleshed out immaculately, with Bradley Whitford and Catherine Keener in their best performances to date, and Caleb Landry Jones in an appropriately, intensely creepy role. But Kaluuya is the star here, and he delivers with zeal a shocking depth and range of emotions. In fact, more often than not its what he doesn't say that delivers the most impact... which is all to say that this masterpiece could not have been accomplished without the masterful direction of Jordan Peele.

Peele builds atmosphere and tension like the Big Bang, dunking you into the mind of the main character while he navigates through very visceral danger.

If you're looking for a film that sets out to entertain first and foremost with shock and terror, but also with poignant social commentary and real philosophical meat to chew on, Get Out is the movie you need to see. You won't regret it.

This isn't Cabin in the Woods, Peele isn't interested in subverting genre conventions. What he has crafted is entirely original and unique, and thankfully free of clichés or stereotypes.

There are no "monsters" here. The real villains are entitlement, egotism, and objectification, and g.d. they are scary!

title: Another great Jordan peele film
review: Recently watched this and us and Jordan peele can do no wrong. Clever original concept and wonderful mix of horror and humour. Well worth a watch

title: A very good and tense film
review: The first act is normal a little cliche but it is not tedious, in a short time the movie shows that something is wrong and since then the inquetación does not stop, the soundtrack helps a lot in that set She passes everything that a horror soundtrack has to have, the the second and third act kill this it's amazing

title: New Perspective
review:
I just watched Get Out for the second time. I loved it the first time and my opinion has not changed. In reading negative reviews, it seems that the main issue is the classification of "horror". This movie does not fit in any one specific genre. It's not supposed to and it shouldn't have to. It is a combination of elements and that's what makes it special. If you are single-minded you won't get this movie.
The second issue I see is folks calling out the racial aspects of the movie. Again, this movie was not made to cater to the white narrative. I think that it makes a lot of viewers who routinely see white people as the "good guys" and saviour of any underdog in a film uncomfortable. Yes, some parts of the movie seem a little "out there" but that is consistent with most movies. That's what makes them good. It seems that it would have been better rated if there were no racial aspects in plot and character development but that is not what Peele wanted to portray. He gave us something to think about beyond the regular.

title: SUPERB MOVIE
review: Intense, thrilling, and very funny. One of the best "horror" movies I can remember.

title: A modern classic
review: This is a great film. Its original in its story line, well put together, building an unsettling atmosphere from early on which carries on even when it lurches into slightly daft horror. There is an undercurrent of black and very dry humour, which whilst not laugh out loud, is noticeable. The performances are all excellent, and the pacing excellent, and the cinematography is quirky and often visually striking. All round an excellent film.

title: Surprising!
review: A movie that makes you believe lots of stuff and in the end proves you wrong in every way with a brilliant story. Funny and scary at the right moments with bits of thought provoking ideas especially under the racism subject. Beautiful, one of the best movies i've watched

title: Top thriller movie with a twist
review:
I don't really enjoy thrillers any more cause all of them Became very common.Blumhouse releases horror movies every year with stupid story lines.(true or dare,happy death day) and the list goes on.

This specific movie Tho starts so well that makes you want to see till the end..

Jordan did an amazing job and the ending was quite a shock.Very clever script and twisty till the end.

title: Movie with a blend of Racism, Conspiracy and Emotion
review:
I thoroughly enjoyed this movie right to the end.
The movie plot was clear in the first 20 minutes so I was waiting for the climax and it was delivered well.

title: A must watch
review: When I first saw the previews for this movie, I thought 'I'm sure Jordan Peele is using the tone of overt racism to make a more interesting point.' I was not disappointed. He sets you up with a barrage of left jabs that started in how the trailers were cut and how the movie plays through most of it's length, and then he delivers a stunning right hook in the major twist of the film. Great portrayals from everyone and a movie that will make you want to watch it again to find the hidden threads that you should've seen and foreshadow what's to come.

title: Enjoyable movie, but a copycat
review:
My biggest problem with this movie is that it won an Oscar for best original screenplay, when actually it's based on a very similar movie that came out over 10 years before it, called the Skeleton Key.

It's an enjoyable movie, but was not a surprise for me, because I could see the twist from a mile away, having seen the Skeleton Key.

title: Just ok. Overrated
review:
Massive holes in this script. It's too long and a veeeeery slow start.

Acting is incredible though and definitely worth a watch.

title: Enjoyed It
review: I didn't have high expectations for this movie if I'm honest. The psychology thriller aspects behind this movie are 100% spot on.

title: Crazy white rich people
review: Wow is what I have to say. Suspenseful and thrilling. Had me on the edge of my seat during the entire movie. I enjoyed it very much. I'm giving it a rating of a ten. One of my favorite movies.

title: Fantastic
review:
It was a very good film and was a nice change as it seemed like an original film.

Film had a huge amount of suspense, a hint of comedy and an Interesting storyline.

The only reason it didn't get a 10 was because I guessed the main parts of the story correctly before it happened meaning it was a little predictable and there seemed to be a lack of chemistry between the main character and his girlfriend but a great film regardless

title: the director too clearly has skills but that chip on his shoulder and a liking for racial humour may hold him back.
review: A measured and endearing enough beginning as a couple proceed to 'meet the parents'. The fact that she is white, the family wealthy and he is black shouldn't make any difference. Should it? He is aprehensive and we understand and to some extent share his concerns, especially as she seems not to have any similar concerns. This is where we are already sensing something is wrong but when things turn 'weird' at the house we rather relax into the notion that this is going to be a horror story, maybe based on the guy's paranoia. Well, this goes way beyond that into 'Society' and 'Stepford Wives' territory, but always with an element of race. This becomes more and more pronounced until the film is about little else and the audience is set up to cheer the death count (of the white folk). Allison Williams is a real discovery and will surely go on to greater things and the director too clearly has skills but that chip on his shoulder and a liking for racial humour may hold him back.

title: Jordan Peele's GET OUT
review: Get Out is like one of the #1 movie in the America. It's Scary and Fun to watch, this is why you go to the movies. Jordan Peele is the mastermind of horror and comedy. Good thing his no M. Night... whatever his name is.

title: A BRILLIANT AND REFRESHING THRILLER
review: A refreshing time enjoying this movie! Through out many repetitive "horror" movies, "Get Out" has a very nice story. A nice plot and psychological horror!

title: Chilling
review: Totally deserved original screenplay but was routing to win best picture

review:
It's only fair to talk about Get Out after Us, simply because I watched Get Out after Us ðŸ˜ŽðŸ’…
.
Get Out also offered a different story line compare to movies I watch. The suspense and music held up the story and kept me on the edge of my seat as well. It was scary in its own way.
.
Moral lesson: you are better than what you think you are
In love with double personality role!

title: Movie Overlook
review:
*SPOILER ALERT* Jordan Peele begins his career in directing by creating one of the best films of the year, tackling multiple societal issues while also giving his audience some laughs and some scares. Get Out strays from the stereotypical horror film by lacking the villainous, scary monster coming from the scary building, woods, etc. Instead it begins with an African-American being the lead character, which is rare when not in an all African-American cast, and the fright of meeting the family of his Caucasian girlfriend. It slowly begins to transition from a regular weekend away into surviving a family of killers and psychopaths. Peele intended the audience to relate to Chris and his fears in every situation with constant close up shots allowing us to feel how uncomfortable he is constantly. It is not just his fears of the crazy family, but societies current awkwardness with interracial couples. Get Out holds a feel of Tobe Hooper with the psychotic killer family seen in Texas Chainsaw Massacre as well as George Romero's Night of the Living Dead feel of entrapment and being stuck in a home.

Peele takes us through a process where Chris begins to face his biggest fear, his mother's death. Chris looks down on the dying deer after hitting it, resembling a similar situation as his mother's hit-and-run where he was powerless. Later in the film that deer reappears as the roles are reversed and it watches Chris as he is about to die. After hitting the deer, the police was called and the officer asks for the ID of Chris even though he was not driving which is Peele's way of showing society how the law can often prejudice. What might be overlooked in that scene is how Rose stands up for Chris as if the focus is on the racism of the officer, when actually it is so that there was never any evidence that the couple had gone up to the estate. If the incident had been filed and Chris would have gone missing, it would lead the police right to the Armitage's. This is just one example of how so many scenes have a double message behind it. Its constant nondiegetic sounds of screeching horror music and jump scares kept the audience on edge, not sure what exactly is gonna happen next.

title: Jordan Peele crushes it in his first film.
review: The film highlights many things that are relevant and prominent issues in our society. This is shown through out the whole course of the film. One example is right when they get there Chris gets weird vibes from the servants of the house and their robotic, emotionless faces when speaking to him. Shortly after Chris has been there, he gets to meet all of Rose's parents friends and family members. Two of the most defining scenes in the movie are when Chris is being hypnotized by Missy and she keeps digging in his mind to make him share an emotional connection from when he was a little boy and he starts to cry because he is back in the moment of when his mom died. Then the camera goes back to the extreme close up of his face with a blank stare and tears dripping from his eyes and jaw dropped as Missy says "Sink" and he just falls into a pit of hopelessness and he is unable to move. The other scene is when all of the relatives are over and he meets Logan King and the interaction is so odd, plain and emotionless. Later in that same setting, Chris is asked if being an African American in the modern day is a disadvantage or advantage. He ends up passing the question off to Logan and he replies that it has "for the most part been very good." Chris rolls his eyes as he nonchalantly pulls out his phone and tries to record his behavior and response but ends up taking a picture with the flash on. Instantly Logan's face goes blank and you see it in his eyes as he almost comes back alive to reality. He instantly looks at Chris as blood is slowly dripping down his face and screams at him to get out. I have seen this scene several times and i still experience chills from head to toe because of the cry for help you hear in his tone of voice is perfect and warns Chris he is in danger. Logan then returns into Missy's office and comes out again emotionless, back stuck in the sunken place. The film does a great job of highlighting prominent societal issues that are present today. This film is a groundbreaking first film for Peele and will be a movie that will be engraved in your head because of how sick and twisted it is. I am excited to see how his future films evolve and turn out.

title: Edge of your seat horror
review:
I watched this film during my Horror Film course this semester. Prior to the last session, I had no idea what the film was about or even that it was so new.

Jordan Peele takes viewers on an emotional journey in this film. Just as the viewer gets comfortable with the direction of the plot, he throws several twist and turns into the mix to keep things fun and exciting. I would have thought that Jordan Peele writing a horror film would be lead in a more comedic direction with a few small elements of scary. He does the exact opposite!! This film left me guessing and on the edge of my seat.

Get Out gives the viewer more of a mental scare, as Peele stays away from the typical cheap jump scares you might be expecting. I could watch this film again and again while still finding a different element to ponder and evaluate.

The actors in the film are just amazing; how they can hold their cool in such obscure situations is baffling. The film deserves awards that it did not have the chance to win. Being able to combine horror and comedy in a well-balanced film deserves much more recognition. I would truly like to see another horror film from Jordan Peele, as I feel he has found a way to create a new, more modern horror film.

To anyone who is looking for the psychological thrill, this film will make you feels many uncomfortable things, but it will offer you the opportunity to see the world in a different way and maybe evaluate your past and future.

title: Falling into the Sunken Place
review:
**** SPOLIER'S AHEAD ****
Get Out was arguably one of the best films of 2017. This is due to how magnificently it was directed and how artistically all the actors portrayed how racism is deeply ingrained in people. The film was at first painted to be a weekend away for Rose (Allison Williams) and her African American Boyfriend Chris (Daniel Kaluuya). On this weekend getaway to Rose's parents' home, Chris quickly realized something was a little off about the family. His suspicions kept growing and growing until he found a box in Rose's old room of all the African American boyfriend's she had had in the past. This is when the film took a turn for the worst and became the most amazingly directed horror film I have ever encountered! Rose's family had captured Chris and were trying to switch his brain with that of an elderly friends so that they could control Chris and use his body. The way that the cast and director executed these following scenes was both artistically beautiful and dictatorially mind blowing. Between director Jordan Peele using many different camera angles such as in scenes like when Chris was hypnotized by Roses mother Missy (Catherine Keener) where Chris was falling into the sunken place. here Peele uses high and low angles to show the dominance of Missy over Chris in this scene and through out the entire movie. Another instance of the amazing artistry going into this film is in the final scenes where Chris is escaping, and all was being revealed to those watching so intently. This section of the film had all rooting for Chris and his escape even though road block after road block were thrown at him. Seeing his escape and his best friend come to the rescue was an amazing ending to a fantastic film. I 100% recommend this film to everyone and will continue doing so until the end of time.

title: Not Everything is Black & White
review:
Get Out is a tremendous film for anyone who is seeing it for the first time, but the amazing part is it's just as good if not better the second time around! More often than not, we as viewers miss elements of the film because we are focused on a different component. Revisiting the movie allowed me to see a lot of the Easter-Eggs I missed the first time around. Additionally, Get Out, hits a 'taboo-topic' that society often has a hard time facing. Jordan Peele masterfully depicts the imbalance in what should be a normal relationship, between a black man (Chris) and a white woman(Rose).
*SPOILER* Early on, we are shown the couple's apartment and we are captivated by a very well kept and stylish apartment, eluding to the fact that the two have a comfortable lifestyle. As Chris and Rose are discussing their plans for the weekend, Chris asks a simple question "Do your parents know that I'm black?" Rose admits they do not but goes on to say how progressive they are and that "if my dad could've voted for Obama for a 3rd term he would've". Later this exact same expression is uttered by Rose's father (Dean) while he is alone with Chris but instead of reassuring us that he is not a bigot it does the opposite and actually makes Dean come off as disingenuous. However, this is Chris's girlfriend's father, so what can he do except kind of chuckle to himself at the insecure white guy?
Why is this important? Because it isn't really an insecurity; the entire Armitage family actually really do admire blacks. In fact: They are obsessed. The natural abilities that many blacks do possess is inherent and the Armitage's want to inherit those abilities...

title: Get Out Review
review:
WARNING: SPOILER ALERT

Get Out was like no other movie I have seen before. This is why I think that it is so special and received so much critical acclaim. The beautiful setting and eerie quietness clash together to give you the sense that something is not right.

First, the story line was great for a horror movie, usually horror movies give you a bit of a freight that lasts for a bit but then subsides. Great horror movies are the ones that stay with you for a long time no matter how hard you try and forget about it. I think one of the scariest parts of the movies is when the party of white people are auctioning off Chris. You thought that slavery is abolished and humans have there own free rights but right in front of you an auction for a person is happening, and they are all okay with it. Another thing that I took away from this movie is that fact that no matter how much you know someone, you can never really know who they are or what they are thinking. This is incredibly freighting and is shown in the movie when Chris finds out he is just another guy that Rose has managed to trick. If you are a fan of The Stepford Wives or Rosemarys Baby then you would like this movie due to the fact that Jordan Peele pays some homage to them. From the 'robotic' like brainwashed slaves to the Armitige cult that seem to have no limits. Overall Get Out was not just a great horror film but a great movie in general that is very controversial and thought provoking if you are willing to look deeper.

title: Warning: Spoilers
review:
!!SPOILER ALERT!! The movie "Get Out" made by the very well-known actor, director, comedian and writer Jordan Peele has to be one of my top three horror movies now after seeing it. The movies cinematography, motifs, jump scares and comedy throughout the movie really drew me in and made it interesting for me. The movie will definitely keep you on the edge of your seat from the constant horror, but will also have you falling out of your seat from laughter. Jordan Peele does a great job tying in certain motifs throughout the movie, but also leaves room open for your own interpretation. The main motif that is seen throughout the entire movie and is very obvious is modern slavery and racial profiling of African Americans in a society dominated by white people. The main focus of the movie that Jordan Peele was trying to point out to everyone was how African Americans are being exploited and mind controlled for the benefit of elite whites.

Throughout the movie we feel bad for what Chris is put and going through. Chris the main character, spends the entire movie surrounded by white people, all of whom we later learn are evil and are attempting to enslave his body. Even the black people Chris meets are already enslaved and are also evil inside. He feels uncomfortable, isn't sure why, and no one empathizes with him about his discomfort. This highlights the effect society, as a whole, has on minorities on a daily basis in a society dominated (numerically and culturally) by white people. The one scene that has everyone talking about the most is when Chris is hypnotized by Rose's mother and Chris falls into another dimension called "The Sunken Place". This scene was so clever and artistic based off of the high, low and long shot camera angles that make the audience feel as if they are falling with Chris into a dark, quiet, lonely abyss. All in all this is a movie that I would highly recommend to everyone and Is one that can be watched more than once and still have the same effect the first time watching it had. I would give this movie a rating of 9/10 because there were no flaws that stood out to me and was very surprising to see how successful this movie came out for how short Jordan Peele has been in the director's seat.

title: A Tempest in a Teacup - The Mind is a Terrible Thing to Waste.
review:
When released in 2017, Jordan Peele's film, Get Out, generated a lot of attention, both positive and negative. For some, Get Out was an instant classic - a multi-genre film that made important observations about the status of racial intolerance in America. For others, Peele's depiction of white America was both formulaic and demeaning. In fact, Peele intended for Get Out to be all of that and more.
The movie appears to be a run-of-the-mill romance where "boy meets girl" (BMG). BMG, of course, is a common plot line that can end either happily or sadly - William Shakespeare made it into a tragedy in Romeo and Juliet; Rob Reiner made it into a comedy in When Harry Met Sally; Stanley Kramer made it into a social cometary in Guess Who's Coming to Dinner. With Get Out, we begin with uncertainty and end in terror as Peele takes us in a completely unexpected direction. Everything is not as it seems, and we are about to see the mask torn from everyday suburban conventionality.
As the movie begins, Chris and his girlfriend Rose are traveling upstate for a weekend visit with her parents, Missy and Dean Armitage. Echoing Guess Who's Coming to Dinner, Chris is concerned that the Armitages will not accept his interracial relationship with their daughter. His concerns seem justified based on their outward pleasantness but obvious nervousness. Besides Chris, there are only three other black people around - two are servants and the other, Dean, is very awkward and odd. Here, Peele evokes the robot-like stiffness of The Stepford Wives - Walter and Georgian are like Stepford servants. As events transpire, Chris - and the audience - discover the disturbing horror that lies beneath the Armitages' outwardly beautiful lake home.
Peele is using the theme of hypnotism throughout the film. Seemingly, in order to cure Chris' smoking habit, Missy hypnotizes Chris by stirring and tapping her teacup. Chris' consciousness is sinking - being oppressed - leaving his physical body under the control of the Armitages. Here, Peele emphasizes the importance of the teacup with a mid-to-low angle, sharp focus shot in which Missy is standing above and controlling both the teacup and Chris.
When Chris takes a photograph, the flash causes Dean to emerge from his trance and he tells Chris to "get out" while you still can. We learn that the guests are actually bidding to own Chris' consciousness. In the finale, Chris is able to fight successfully to retain his very existence by breaking both the teacup and its hypnotic power. Yet, we are left to ponder some troubling truths about racism in post-Obama America and the need to get "woke" from the hypnotic influences of modern culture.

title: Traditional Meets Innovative
review:
The feeling of being watched is a classic element in most horror movies but in Get Out (2017), written and directed by Jordan Peele, the audience gets to live vicariously through the main character Chris as he has an intensely different experience meeting his new girlfriend's parents. This film has the classic jump scare elements sprinkled in to the suspense the audience experiences waiting for something triggering to happen to confirm our suspicions about the family. Throughout the film, Peele uses quick cuts and the nondiegetic music of a screeching violin, which is later realized as a leitmotif, to not warn the viewers that there is more going on with this family that we can imagine. We forced to align with Chris and his emotions by not being fully omniscient in many aspects. Even though the viewers see things such as the silent auction, we are unaware of the true meaning of what being bought entails. Each twist and turn of the plot is just as much of a surprise to us as it is to him.
The last few scenes of the movie seem to hone in to the classic horror elements. In addition to the unveiling that Chris' girlfriend is also in on his capture, these scenes are where the blood and killings are displayed in true horror fashion. The blood from the brain surgery in addition to the blood from the killings of the parents, brother, girlfriend, housekeeper and groundskeeper, helps the movie come full circle in ending with the gruesome imagery of a horror movie. This film keeps the audience constantly on the edge of their seat while hoping Chris can find some way out of this monstrous house.

title: The Artistry of Get Out
review:
SPOILER ALERT

"Get Out" This award winning film did a great job showing the brutally honest truth of racism in America. This film was one big contradiction. It shows that white privilege is a real life and is happening but at the same time; while also showing that white people are envious of black people because of all the stereotypes. There were many times in the film when someone would hint at their obsession with Chris in being a stereotype of African Americans. For instance, "black is in fashion", the athletic ability, genes, etc. Although they love being white it makes you think, is white really the superior race? Dean Armitage had mentioned to Chris about the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, Germany where the US track star won gold, not allowing the Aryan race to be superior. This film depicts the courage African Americans must have in order to stand up for themselves and take pride in their culture. The overall message in this film relates to one of the most real situations happening in America. In addition, when you analyze the film from an artistic viewpoint, you'll understand the film is an award winning film. Every camera angle, sound, lighting, facial expression was done so well in this film. What I thought was truly amazing was the amount of foreshadowing there was. For example, when Chris and Rose are on the was the Armitage household and hit the deer, Chris goes over to see it, which leads to the forest creating a tunnel where it separates the real world (life) to in the darkness of the woods (death). A similar scene is shown during Chris's dream, and finally we are shown what is being foreshadowed. When Chris is hypnotized and falls into the absolute darkness of the "SUNKEN PLACE", Chris goes from real life to the darkness of the Sunken Place. The camera angle used when showing the Sunken Place gives the audience the sense of being in there with Chris. The extreme long shot makes it seem like we have actually sunk down into our minds. The long shot also portrays like we are watching what's happening through the inside of a television set. The close ups of Chris on the chairs while being hypnotized really shows the audience the mental pain and torture he is going through -- eyes bulging, tears flowing, sweat dripping -- we get every detail of what he is going through in these moments. The sound editing and score of this film is what made the film as suspenseful as it is. The screechy violin gives you the sense of unsettlement, the same as the nails scratching on the chairs almost makes you shiver or cover your ears because of how unsettling it is. The use of silence in the film enhances the creepiness of the film. When Chris goes upstairs to check his phone and the entire party in unison becomes silent. In the Sunken Place, Chris is unable to speak; we see his mouth move but nothing comes out. The overall message and the artistry of this film was just amazing and being produced by a well known comedian Jordan Peele. He did a wonderful job of creating very real life horror film. RATE: 9.3/10

title: A Revisionist View of the Horror/Thriller Genre
review:
SPOILER ALERT
Everyone's felt like an unwanted outsider at some point in their life. Get Out, directed and written by Jordan Peele, takes this feeling to a whole new level. This horror film seems to stray from the stereotypical horror genre with its distinct lack of creepy monster or dark, foreboding woods. Instead, the audience is treated to the close up shot to give us an understanding of how Chris, the main character, is feeling. We are constantly at Chris's eye level, which allows us to sympathize with his plight. However, Peele ditches the clichÃ©d extreme close up for an unshakeable sensation of being constantly watched. The audience is treated to several jump scares at the beginning to create the overall sense of never quite being alone. Get Out also replaces the overt, thrilling hunting scenes of John Carpenter and Tobe Hooper with the perplexing impression that a noose is tightening around Chris's neck. The nondiegetic music, with its screeching violins and unsettling silence, amps up the uncanny knowledge that Chris is in danger, but the lack of clear violence denies the primitive feelings of prey. To add to the uneasiness, the diegetic sounds of silence and eerie cricket chirps takes the audience at the edge of their seats as they wonder what happens next.
Even though Get Out may seem like just another psychological thriller, it has many characteristics that horror movie enthusiasts expect to see. Even though the audience seems to hold its breath for most of the movie, horror elements start bleed into the movie during the final scenes when Chris is being taken for the final procedure. Sudden cuts from Jeremy to Chris jar the audience out of the sense of security they'd been lulled in. The high angle shot of Jeremy's supposed corpse lets us know who is in control. Suddenly, things move quickly, taking on a more frenzied, horror film feel. We are allowed to sit in suspense as Dean Armitage waits for his son's return. Abruptly, Chris runs him through with a deer trophy and watches him die. After several more frantic fights to the death, Chris finds himself on the road with the female killer. Just like Sally in Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Chris was rescued by someone from outside the 'terrible place' and rides away from his nightmare. Overall, the movie was a well-planned trip into the psyche of a hunted man.

title: Creepy, but with humor
review: Great acting, excellent dramaturgy, very atmospheric visuals. The crazy and very creepy plot is often mellowed out with funny lines.

title: Being John Malkovich 2
review:
This reminded me of League Of Gentlemen, which was a British black comedy series (black as in very dark humour), about an outsider visiting a village full of very strange 'locals'. Tonally this didn't come across as horror as much as it did a black comedy.

It's a decent premise and that feeling of being the outsider in a group of people pretending to accept you is almost tangible.

Where the comedy comes in is in the behaviour of the other 'ethnic minorities' as they respond to Chris (It's more demented than scary as is Caleb Landry Jones Brad Pitt impersonation), as well as the whole idea behind the story - kind of like a sinister Being John Malkovich (also starring Catherine Keener), which makes sense as upon further reading I have discovered this is the unofficial sequel to BJM.

Still, the film has its moments and you find yourself really rooting for Chris willing him to get the hell out of there.

The film missed a trick by confronting the horrors of racism in an everyday way instead opting for almost cinema of the absurd with more than a few surreal Danny Boylian moments.

Violence as the black man's only method of resolution also seems dubious. Other than that it was an enjoyable popcorn movie. Not sure it was worthy of an Oscar. It wasn't that good.

title: Get Out Keeps Running To The Top Of The Charts For The Best Original Screenplay
review:
In the film "Get Out" by the director Jordan Peele, he uses different methods throughout the film that bring up the painful history of the racism in America. The actual suspenseful effect that the film had was very powerful, some parts of the movie made me feel like the actions that some of the characters were partaking in were happening to me.
This film is horror/suspense based and it is centered by a interracial couple, the African American male Chris (Daniel Kaluuya), and the female, Rose (Allison Williams). The couple had been dating for over some months now and it was time for Chris to meet Rose's parents. Get out takes you through a various ride of emotions almost feeling like I was connecting to some of the characters at times. Chris had previous worries about his race towards her parents, once they arrived to her parents house and are a bit more settled in, Chris begins to feel more paranoid on what they are hiding from him. As the film goes on in kind of turns into more of a horror film having all of the audience on the edge of their seats.
Jordan Peele uses such a unique way of truly attracting the audience to the film, considering the music as well. The Swahili song that gets recognized throughout the whole film by being in the background keeps an ongoing eerie feeling that something bad is yet to come. Peele does an absolutely outstanding job showing the similarities between all the black characters in the movie at Rose's parents house. In the film the acting is incredible, it almost made me forget who the the actors were because they were playing the part of their characters so well.
One of my favorite parts in the movie shows how I was able to connect to some of the racial stereotypes Chris was facing during a family party at Rose's parents house. At some times Jordan Peele throws in some of his comedic sense of humor at some of the almost screeching horrific parts of the film.
Get Out brings up the sad and hurtful passed of racism but also it connects to the way Chris feels when he is in the sunken place. Because he felt like he had no control over what was going on, same with the racism in the past and how many African Americans were being controlled. This film also connects back to an older suspenseful like horror film called The Shining. Jordan Peele was very inspired by this movie because it gave Get Out more twisted clues at times that no one would notice until the second time they watch it. From the beginning to the end of the movie Peele has everyone on their toes horrified on what's to come. A reference to another director/author that could've been used to make this film would've been Stephen King, just because he makes horror films that include some comedic features that seep through during some of the more suspenseful parts of the film.
Some ways Jordan Peele could've made this movie more prestigious is if he hadn't had the funny black TSA character Rod who is Chris's friend, stop out of the police car to save Chris but instead have actual police officers step out while he is in the middle of trying to save himself from Rose. This change would've made the whole audience stand up in anger and start to yell at the characters to try and help them.
This will forever be one of my recent favorite horror films, it gave me all the emotions one could have within an hour and forty five minutes. Until Jordan Peele comes out with another movie that matches this one it will be on the top of the scale in my mind and in the category of suspenseful films as well. I am pretty positive the whole audience was pleased after watching this incredible film, it was definitely worth the wait and seeing it in the theater! Get Out is highly recommended to watch and then watch it again and notice the little things that show some of the hidden secrets that show what they are hiding at the end.

title: Talking About a Good Thriller.
review:
It would be the first one to defend films with visual and psychological impact. Whether other critics want to accept it or not, the impact on the senses of the viewer is one of the main reasons why cinema, nowadays, is considered the Seventh Art. The films that move the viewer in deeper ways tend to be those that go down in history and become cult films. Today, the day I write this review, I can say that one of those films competed on the big stage of world cinema in the category of Best Film of 2017. Get Out, directed by Jordan Peele and starring Daniel Kaluuya, presents a story that, as it advances, gets darker and darker, generating depth at a frenetic speed. There are even points in the film that, at least personally, one asks: How did all end up like this? This, more than being a con, proves to be one of the reasons why this production is so amazing.

It should be emphasized that this production does not skimp on symbolism, especially aimed at the marginalization of African-Americans and the control exerted by the higher spheres of power, which in the film is represented as a very powerful group of white people. Somehow, some of the scenes reminded me of some of Malcolm X's discourses about ideological whitening and the need of the African-American to emulate the customs of white people to have a status in society. An example is the attitude of the black slaves, who insist that they do not respond to anyone, that they are cured, that their captors have freed them and a long etcetera. The movie in its narrative suggests a great parallelism to the identity theft committed against the African-American, forced to changing its essence to be a functional part of society, and it can be said that it (the movie) does so in a masterly way.

The house of the Armitage family, along with its guests, is full of clichÃ©s. Customs that are often seen as a characteristic of the white man, where a black person is mentioned that exceeded everyone's expectations, taking as examples Jesse Owens in athletics, Tiger Woods in golf and even Barack Obama winning the presidency of the United States. It reflects a feeling even of envy on the part of the white people, which becomes evident towards the end of the film and in the antagonistic intentions of the family. All of this gathers meaning as time passes, which creates the impression that, at the end of the film, the viewer has seen a puzzle coming together. Very good handling of symbolism, excellent script.

You can see that a fundamental part of the film are those details of tension, suspense and even certain scenes directly targeting a more terrorific path. In this respect, the use of sounds and musical ambience play a key role, which proves to be of high quality in this production. Continuous movements and twists in the plot, which do nothing but create even more visual and psychological impact on the mind of the viewer. I would not be surprised to see someone just watching this movie saying: What did I just saw? It is pleasing to mention however that the above said, in this particular case, adds to the quality of the film instead of taking it away. Very good work by the director and the cast, who proved that they had the exact amount of characters to present the story and that all of them have a degree of depth at least worthy of consideration. Daniel Kaluuya provides a very good performance. However, It was a long shot against Gary Oldman for the 2017 Oscar in this category.

Summing it up, I consider that this film is a perfect combination between the representation of a social stigma and a quality thriller. It is an excellent bet, and had each of its four Oscar nominations and its win as best original screenplay more than well deserved. I highly recommend this film, and I think it will become a movie that will overcome the barriers of time.

title: If You Haven't Seen This Film You Can "GET OUT"!
review:
First time director Jordan Peele (as in the one of lead stars from the comedy TV series Key & Peele) brings us a new, fresh and very unexpected film for cinema lovers. Get Out is aimed at the genre of horror and thriller with a little touch of good humor. Get Out tells the story of a young African-American male, "Chris", who agrees to finally visit his Caucasian girlfriend's family at their home estate.

Upon arrival everything appears to be what you would expect when meeting a girlfriend's parents. However, within a matter of time...strange things start occurring around the family home. Chris begins to become concerned and curious. And, in order not to spoil the film's plot, this is all I'm going to say.

While watching Get Out I discovered that I was having a really great time. With so many sequels and reboots this year, Get Out felt like I was breathing in clean fresh air. The genre of Horror/Thriller must be very challenging by today's standards to come up with fresh and creative ideas. Considering, as I said above, this is Jordan Peele's 1st official film with him directing, the end results are very good.

Get Out does a fantastic job at keeping the film suspenseful and the viewer hooked until the end credits. At no point did I check my watch because I was bored. I was completely pulled into the film's plot and I wasn't leaving the cinemas until I got answers and explanations for all the strange things Chris was discovering around him.

The film also has an outstanding audio track. The clever use of eerie music throughout will suddenly switch to a well known classic song, letting the audience know that it's ok to have fun with this movie. Jordan Peele's camera work is also something to be praised. The clever use of multiple angles and slow panning is something that I would call "Hitchcock" style. Many times throughout the film I was watching something that shocked me or had me in suspense, but no matter what, I couldn't help it but to have a smile on my face too. When I see s scary movie, I am a man who doesn't normally jump out of his seat. But this movie, got me to jump twice (once even yelling at the cinema screen!).

Get Out is a film that Finesse Movie Reviews suggest you shouldn't miss in 2017. I feel it's a film that will really surprise and I recommend this for those who enjoy an interesting story with suspenseful moments. The film does have a couple of faults to be sure, but they are so minor I refuse to talk about them online. I found the film to be unpredictable, but even when I knew something was coming... I was so keen to see it happen as this film had me very Invested in it.

9.1/10 Walkden Entertainment

title: A perfect horror movie.
review: Where do I begin? Everything worked in this movie flawlessly. Things I thought would be unfunny or stupid worked, such as Ned The Security Guard or simply the ideas of slavery still going on secretly is actually done great. The twists and turns, the family getting killed, the imagery, the creepy moments, a silent auction disguised as playing bingo. IT'S AMAZING AND SOMETIMES HILARIOUS IN THE BEST WAY. There were two scenes where Ned was scared for Chris (the main character) and he complains to the police and it was REALLY DAMN FUNNY. The second scene is when Ned is called by Rose (Chris' girlfriend) and tries to seduce Ned in the most robotic and unsubtle way and it's HILARIOUS. Moments that were scary were actually scary and nerve-racking such as when he's watching the TV while kidnapped or simply becoming hypnotized for the first time. All around, I loved this movie and I'm definitely going to see it again. 10/10.

title: Promising but not extraordinary
review:
I like the whole concept and themes which it tries to present. Even I liked the performances but I was expecting a bit more (maybe because of the hype it got).
Perhaps the film tries very hard to shove down the message down our throats and maybe that's why I didn't enjoy the thrill much. And the climax for me was a bit dull. "Black guy triumphs the White guy" narrative seems too one dimensional for me. It's what I will want in real life but don't exactly expect in a thriller to be honest.

title: Pop Culture Thoughts
review: Coming seemingly out of nowhere, Jordan Peele's "Get Out" is likely unprecedented in cinema history: A story excoriating white racism that deals with social issues without succumbing to facile conclusions, written and directed by a black man whose vision is clearly not compromised. But even beyond those distinctions, the movie itself is absolutely fantastic - it's unpredictable without being inscrutable, extraordinarily well acted without histrionics, and benefits from a riveting, pulse-pounding climax. Daniel Kaluuya turns in a knockout performance, with several stand-out scenes where Kaluuya communicates his character's growing suspicions without changing the expression on his face. Ultimately this is one of those few movies where the buzz is more than warranted, with Peele delivering a gut punch of a movie that is sure to be dissected and discussed for decades to come.

title: Entertaining
review: Truly an incredible movie from beginning to end, the suspense and end twist was everything that it needed to be. nothing was forced and typical horror movie tropes are lost making this a fresh unique take on the genre. can't wait for more from peele. 9/10

Not my genre, but that was consistently absolutely terrifying. lovely main character and rod and sid are great. would've liked to get the assurance that everything gets unearthed and dealt with at the end (bit worrying since there were so many rich people showing up to that thing/ the story seems unbelievable/ chris is black and could be framed for murder rather than self defence anyway) but i guess if you're going for thriller that part was done with. next is just the horrors of more racism i guess.

title: A masterpiece of modern day horror and suspense
review: Monsters, nope. Gore, nope. Gratuitous nudity, nope.... scary as f??? Yes!! This movie is absolutely brilliant. From the first second of this movie you know things "just ain't right". Like the reality of today's society, people are putting on smiles as if everything is perfect, yet there is something barely under the surface that is is more than disturbing. I don't want to spoil anything, but rent this thriller that will have you laughing, and curled up in the corner all at the same time. Not one "jump scare" in the entire movie, yet effectively immerses you into a dark place that is much more frightening than a camp in the woods with a hockey mask wearing maniac. At least there you know what to be afraid of. Rent this tosay

title: Scary
review: It scares me especially when I got to know the truth

title: Wow. As good as people have told you it would be.
review:
So it feels silly reviewing a movie that everyone has either seen or reviewed but I do these for me so here goes.

;TLDR - Very interesting movie, really makes you think and gets you hooked right in. Lots of feelings of anxiety and confusion. Very well shot and put together feels like an episode of The Twilight Zone with a rather abrupt but solid ending.

I've held off watching Get Out for while now so I figured I should probably get to it. The movie is often listed as a thriller/horror/comedy which seems like the odd mix of genres but the blend works well. The comedy isn't overly there ruining the suspense or terror, it's very well included in the form of 1 character from time to time.

The tension created right off the bat and the awkward feeling of "something is not right here" is great and makes you very interested in what is happening/going to happen. About 30 minutes into the movie you start to think "am I watching a modern episode of The Twilight Zone?" (How fitting with Jordan Peele being the new host of the show). At first you might feel like the movie is predictable or that you know what's going to happen and in some ways you may be right but there are still some interesting story points that you might not expect. Overall it was very enjoyable very captivating and a pretty fabtastic movie in the end.

title: Great flick
review:
I really liked this movie. I thought it had a lot to say about current day racism. The white people in this film viewed black people as physically valuable but did not recognize any value in their minds or any other aspect of their beings. The quote "black is in fashion" indicates that black people are just a commodity for white people to use - and in this film, they do use them in the extreme.

I loved the ending, I loved the kill scenes, I loved the feeling of being trapped that this movie made me feel. I was able to really sympathize with Chris (as much as a white woman can) and I loved that he felt fleshed out as a character. I liked him as a person, and I felt this made me better able to empathize with him.

This was my second viewing and I have to say I really appreciated the "something's not right" hints portrayed by Georgina, Walter, and Logan, as well as the white people in this film, more the second time around. For me, knowing the reason behind the odd behavior made it that much more horrific for me.

My only problems with this film were the use of hypnotism because I just don't buy that it could be that powerful, the use of neurosurgery because there are too many holes there like how were memories and personality transferred in tact to the other person, and I felt the comedic aspect the character Rod brought to the film did not fit in with the overall plot. As much as I appreciate horror comedy, it did not work for me in this particular film.

title: Breath of life to a dying horror genre
review: It's been a long while since a solid "secret society" horror movie was released, and with a few nice elements into the mix (not thinking of black being a slave, but having various advantages like being of bigger build, bigger dicks or more fashionable these days). 9/10

title: A modern masterpiece
review: Great casting choices- Daniel Kaluuya, Lakeith Stanfield, Catherine Keener, Caleb Landry Jones just to name a few. First time director Jordan Peele delivers a powerful debut. The symbolism and pacing felt so effortless and yet so well thought out. I still tell people how good this movie is.

title: Three words : Ingenous, Captivating and Symbolic.
review:
It took me almost a year before I started watching this movie. On the surface, it was not the kind of movie that particularly appealed to me, and I've always told myself : it's just an umpteenth story about racism.
And yet, surprise ! It is easy to identify the atmosphere of the film from the very first minutes. What I like about this film is that it is full of small details that feed our understanding of the plot and I find it so ingenious.
Not to mention the acting, which, unsurprisingly, has amazed the audience. We often talk about Daniel Kaluuya's extraordinary performance, but not enough of Allison Williams's. She plays, in my opinion, the darkest character in the film. The moment we discover that in fact she was a villain was truly shocking. I didn't expect this plot twist. This is why I think that the moment when Chris discovers the photos is the best scene, and also one of the best anti-climaxes I've ever witnessed in my entire life.
This movie is a solid 9/10.

This is a great film that is worth the watch. So check it out and enjoy it.

title: Highly original
review: Get out. Marketed as a horror but I'd say more psychological thriller with added political and social commentary. 'Tealeaf' from Psychoville plays an African American dating a white middle class American girl. He meets her parents at their house after four months together and they act a bit like David Brent when he's around the black guy in The Office (we voted Obama etc). The humour soon turns to tension as events start to take a turn for the peculiar - particularly amongst the household's black 'servants'. A very original and thoroughly engaging 8 out of ten.

People who are easily deceived by the good manners of their supposedly called significant other can be disaster if you give your full trust even less than five months of dating stage. This is one of the lessons we shoud always remember. You can give your trust to them but don't ever be deceived. Always think about the worst case scenarios. At least you still got yourself to protect.

And hey, this movie includes racism so you better get ready for anything disturbances. You'll be shocked as to why they are doing this to them.

If you got any chance, GET OUT.



Abe Rates: 7/10

title: A serviceable and entertaining horror film
review: A serviceable and entertaining horror film with some sinister moments and some funny moments. Very predictable story and events, as the almost immediate awkwardness from the characters gives a lot of the mystery away, but there are still some good clues and a tidy, if somewhat convenient, ending. I think it should have done more with the imagery, psychological mind games and potentially deep-rooted racism aspects of the plot.

title: Very similar to a movie called THE SKELETON KEY
review:
The movie GET OUT was exceptional, incredibly well done. The actors were believable and the story well written. However I can't help but see the similarities to the movie THE SKELETON KEY starring Kate Hudson.
In SKELETON KEY, Kate Hudson plays a woman named Caroline Ellis. Caroline goes to work for an older couple (Violet & Ben) where she discovers voodoo and witch craft are being used. It isn't until the very end - when we discover that the older couple brought Caroline to their home to steal her body and basically the old woman would take over Caroline's body but still be Violet's mind. They use something called hoodoo and Caroline's mind switches to Violets old body and Violet moves into Caroline's young body. The end.
In GET OUT, the story is exactly the same. Rose brings her black boyfriend Chris, to her parents house for the weekend, where several rich (older) whites couples bid at auction to buy the rights to Chris' body. Chris is hypnotized by Rose's mother Missy, with the intent that Rose's father Dean would perform a brain transplant. They had apparently been doing this "operation" for some time, at least 12 that we know of. Luckily, Chris figures this out just in time and with some very good luck he manages to kill all 6 people involved and gets away. It is the same story, older people who wanted new young bodies, without giving up their own personalities and past experiences. Both movies are very good, although I liked The Skeleton Key a bit better because I saw that one first. The movie Get Out is excellent.

title: Very scary
review: This is one of the scariest movie I have seen. Not quite has scary has the original Texas chainsaw massacre from 1974. The original Friday the 13th from 1980 is also scarier. The original Halloween from 1978 is also scary. A Nightmare on elm street 3 the dream worries is also scarier. But this is a lot better Then The silence of the lambs could every be. This movie has a great story line. It also has great acting.

title: pretty good
review:
First of all, i think its reasonable to mention that im white, and i didn't really think it was scary at all (and im terrible with horror usually). however, it sure as hell isnt the comedy some people make it out to be either. this is also one of those things that are each to their own though, so others may find it way more terriying than i did, which i understand.

with that out of the way, i really liked the script, and i thought the concept was incredibly interesting. its one of the most original horror films ive seen in a long while, and the acting was incredible. the editing was great too, although i remember it defintly followed a specific (over exaggerated? but only in a good way) style of acting, which i applaud them for honestly. the reason i didnt really think much of this movie, honestly just comes down to preference.

conclusion: not everyones cup of tea, not really mine either, but i'd still reccomend it, either way its definitely entertaining.

title: Get Out is easily one of the best horror films of 2017.
review:
TL;DR: It's not surprise that Get Out shot to the top of the box office when it was released. It's a smart critique of how racism still exists today wrapped up into a modern-day horror masterpiece. Hands down one of my favorite horror movies of 2017.

The LONG version: Chances are if you're a fan of horror, you've seen most (if not all) of the movies I've reviewed. I don't review first-run movies that are still in theaters. Instead, I stick to movies I'm able to enjoy in the comfort of my own home high as hell. Which reminds me... Before I dive in, I need to disclose one small detail. I enjoy watching movies (especially horror) while high. Apologies in advance to anyone out there who that may offend. That said, it all boils down to harm reduction. Maybe it's just me being overly cautious, but I'm not comfortable getting intoxicated in public, let alone a movie theater. And that goes for alcohol too. I want as much control over my environment as possible when I decide to get baked.

So yeah, that was a long explanation as to why I don't review movies that are still in theaters. But I felt the need since there have been a few requests from people to review flicks that haven't reached home video yet.

Riveting, isn't it?

Which brings me to Get Out - a movie I'm certain every horror fan has already watched. If you haven't, shame on you! But if you've read any of my previous reviews, chances are that's not why you're here. Yes, you've probably seen the movie. The question you have is should you watch it again... stoned? To find out the answer, we must first find out which strain was selected for this particular evening.

It was a Friday night so I decided to change things up with a sativa and grabbed some legendary Sour Diesel. It wouldn't help my insomnia, but it did get my mind and body into a comfortably euphoric state while also easing my joint pain. It didn't produce any couch-lock effects that I appreciate while watching TV, but I was too high to care.

Sour Diesel buds are light green in color with rust colored hairs and packed with frosty trichomes. Just as the name implies, the smell is pungent and heavy on the diesel with a touch of pine. After sparking up the bowl and taking my first rip I was able to appreciate the earthy flavor and smooth inhale. I may have kept the smoke in my lungs for a bit too long because the exhale wasn't as smooth and triggered a pretty intense coughing fit. My lungs tightened up and my head instantly felt like it was 5 pounds heavier. Perfect time to get the movie started!

Get Out is the brainchild of first-time director Jordan Peele and begins innocently enough with a black man walking down a suburban street at night. The sidewalks are empty and only a single car is on the road slowly following the man. When he stops walking, the car stops. When he decides to "keep on walkin'" the car begins to follow again. Everyone who's ever walked alone at night can relate to this type of fear and the movie perfectly executes the tension and inner-dialogue going on in his mind. My heart raced as I anxiously watched the scene play out knowing it wasn't going to end well. Of course, there's a good chance my racing heart was a side-effect of the Sour Diesel bombarding my endocannabinoid system, but whatever. The man eventually decides to change course in an attempt to avoid the trailing car. It's no use. A masked assailant sneaks up on the man, chokes him out, then stuffs him into the trunk of the car and drives off. Part of its visceral quality is that it's all presented as a single shot. No cuts. Perfectly choreographed to make you feel like you're right there watching it happen in real time. It's terrifying, it's uncomfortable, and that's how the movie starts! Buckle up, kids. It's going to be a crazy ride!

The movie stars Daniel Kaluuya (Chris) and Allison Williams (Rose) as an interracial couple who's off to meet Rose's parents and spend the weekend at their suburban home. Chris is worried about how Rose's parents will react when they meet him since she's never told them he was black. But Rose assures him that everything will be fine. When they ultimately arrive at the house, everything does appear to be fine... maybe a little too fine. The father, Dean, a doctor (Bradley Whitford) and mother, Missy, a psychiatrist (Catherine Keener) seem like they're the definition of the perfect American marriage. Things get a little odd when their live-in servants, a maid and gardener, are introduced - both of whom are black. It's hard not to immediately think "slave". But once again, Rose comes in to ease Chris' worries. She explains that they both cared for her ailing grandparents when they were alive. Once they passed, they were already "part of the family" so her parents simply allowed them to stay. Again... maybe a little too nice.

It's no wonder this movie shot to number one in the box office when it was released. It's a smart critique of how racism still exists today wrapped up into a modern-day horror masterpiece. Horror is the mechanism, but exposing how racism still lingers in places you wouldn't expect is the message. Often times the most racist are those who are also the most outwardly "progressive". This point is driven home when Rose's father expresses to Chris that he "would've voted for Obama for a third time if I could". Maybe it's just me, but that sounds like a bit of overcompensation... almost defensive. He might well have said, "I have a lot of black friends." Are either of those phrases outwardly racist? No. But that's the whole point of the movie.

That evening Chris sneaks out for a smoke (he's trying to quit) and witnesses both of the servants acting strange. The gardener sprints around the estate nearly running right into him and the maid appears in a trance-like state staring out her window. When Chris finishes his smoke and returns to the house, Missy spots him and invites him to chat. He sits across from her and Missy begins going to work by first asking if he's comfortable. Then she asks if he smokes in front of her daughter and offers to help him quit through hypnosis. Her questioning becomes more and more personal until she suggests he "sink into the floor". And sink he does. The now famous image of Chris paralyzed, horrified, helpless, tears streaming down his face. He falls deep into the "sunken place" as he looks through a window into the conscious world. His screams are silent. The whole scene is unnerving. In fact, I'm happy I didn't choose a more psychedelic strain like Gorilla Glue #4 or Blackwater that make me feel like I'm sinking into an underworld. Probably would've been too much for my mind to comprehend. And then just like that, he wakes. Safe in bed he tells himself it was just a nightmare.

This is when Get Out really turns up the heat. The events that unfold continue to heighten and become even more uncomfortable until the terrifying climax when the real motive behind the meet-the-parents weekend getaway is uncovered. If you've seen the movie you're already well aware of the the twists and turns of the final act. If not, you'll thank me later that I didn't spoil anything.

title: Get out and watch the movie!
review:
Finished watching Get Out. I thoroughly enjoyed watching the film. The movie genuinely kept me guessing and perfectly used suspense to keep me hooked. It was a deep movie on many levels that really felt rewarding to watch. I really don't have anything to criticize about the movie. The acting was great, the dialogue was amazing, and the story kept me on the edge of my seat. What more can you ask for?

The movie also made excellent use of its score and sound to heightened the tension in the film. A great suspense thriller overall, 9 out of 10.

title: Like a long episode of black mirror
review: It's dark, funny, and very entertaining. I'm a big fan of Black Mirror, and this movie gave me that same eerie feeling. The movie gives a lot of hints as to what's going on, and you can figure out what's going to happen pretty early if you pay attention. Which I don't mind, really. It's still entertaining, funny, and just as scary as I like a movie to be. It's not a horror movie, though.

title: Exceptional and ground-breaking!
review: Get Out is an instant classic! I had no idea what I was getting into when sitting down to watch this, but I was interested to see what Jordan Peele had in store! I love horror films that try not to focus on the scary aspects, rather they will focus on the overall ambiance of the film, setting up events that will happen later on, I also want to point out that the movie has it's fair share of humor and it really works! Get Out is amazingly made!

title: Realistic twist
review:
Disclaimer! If you watch this black-mirror style movie you might start doubting the true motives behind inter-human relationships, become skeptical of your significant others actions and mainly start questioning the nature of your socializing world. I'm dramatizing.

However, the plot of the movie is superb, acting is amazing and the soundtrack fits perfectly. Unfortunately quite unscientific when it come to its medical procedures and references to hypnosis.Nevertheless, still a worth watch. Touching on the inherent xenophobia of humans and highly ting its subtle manifestations, the movie portraits the vestiges of alleged race differences and white supremacy.

It will keep you engaged and excited. It makes a great job of spiking emotions and getting you out of your monotonous existence.

review: I missed my chance to watch Get Out when the movie still the hotest topic of moviegoers in 2017 and avoid the movie like the plague after the director Jordan Peele won a Oscar of 2018 not because I'm trying to look edgy but I'm scared of all the hype around the movie at the time ruin the movie for me.Today I finally watch Get Out for the first time alone at my house and it the movie it pretty good to be honest but it still feel overrated for some reason.Get Out is a horror-comedy movie with a big message about all kind of discrimination that a person like me never experience in a very interesting and sometime funny way.The movie never go down with the thrill and the acting from the beginning to the end with is surprise me cause I'm always looking for a bad moment in horror movie to laugh at. It suck that I already saw some glimpse of Get Out before in movies like You're Next and The Wicker Man but nonetheless it still cool when a first time director with a heavy comedy background made a horror movie that win a Oscar for Best Original Screenplay the award that I think is the hardest to even nominated when Hollywood nowadays suffer from the lack of imagination

title: Love the lady cop! Worth ordering on demand for once
review:
Fun and true and POSSIBLY actually true somewhere. Not like the reich woukdnt have tried it ... You cant just look like someone & the whole personality would be hard to fake so it was clever with all the cultural appropriation talk eh?...& of course funny too. Im a fan of Key & Peele& hope they make more films even if directing. I thought the grandma / maid should have been nominated. Yes it was brief but so effective . I recall Judy Dench getting an award for playing a queen for 5 mins in a movie. Nonetheless this an instant classic in the post-Obama era. NB. I love how ppl say i could care less when they MEAN I couldnt care less......but thats Jeffrey Dalmer's business...LOL 
 But ANYWAY hope to see these actors again in movies. PS I Love the Darius Character on Atlanta, such a lovable persona on that show.

title: reveals much about America in 2017
review: I love that a movie released in February is still dominating the conversation when it comes to best movies of the year. The tightrope the movie walks between racism and liberal guilt is impressive, and it makes the more supernatural aspects more believable. Personally, I love the attack on smug attitude of the rich and powerful, as well as I jump for joy as more original stories like this one come to light. The special effects used in the "sunken place" are like nothing I have ever seen in a mainstream Hollywood movie. It may not be a perfect movie, but it is perfectly rabid and full of ideas that it is unafraid to throw at the audience, and in a way that is more respectable than being formally perfect. That so many people of all races find something to love about this movie reveals much about America in 2017.....i'm sure there are many essays that could/ will be written about it.
