title: Biggest Surprise of 2017
review:
This film was a huge surprise last year to say the least, what an incredible film that to be honest I though I wasn't going to like in the beginning. However I do feel as if this film was marketed wrong because this film isn't a horror, its a psychological thriller with brilliant twists.

Jordan Peele out of nowhere has given us a film that is truly remarkable and sends a strong message underneath at will appeal to everyone. The directing is very good but then when you find out this is his directorial debut, it is jaw dropping how good this film is. This could be the start of a very interesting and promising directing career. The writing as well is mind numbingly weird, how did he come up with this story it is creepy as hell. I'll get onto the writing achievement a bit more later on in the review. Fantastic work!

The cast are fantastic all across the board, however there are two that standout above the rest. Firstly Daniel Kaluuya, yes at last this man has mean given a big juicy role in a film, for me one of the most underrated actors working today. I am so glad that he was given a chance and my word did he not disappoint. His character is the audiences perspective of the story unfolding in front of us in a way. As soon as the film starts you instantly have a connection to his character and you end up routing for him. The other standout for very different reasons is Allison Williams, she really is the foundation of the film because if her deception doesn't work then the whole film around her will fail. The first time I saw the film, over a year ago now, I was astounded by how I didn't see the character switch from her coming. Williams had portrayed the innocent girlfriend so brilliantly that I believed it and that she as just as innocent and good as Kaluuya. Extremely good acting from both of them.

Small shoutout should go to Lil Rel Howery as "Rod", a hilarious character that is a pure joy to watch and actually serves a purpose in the story rather just a funny side character.

The biggest positive I take from the film is the re-watchability of the film. As soon as I saw it the first time I instantly wanted to watch it again because the film would take on a whole new meaning. Character motivations in the beginning mean show much different , now knowing the ending. For instant when "Chris" and "Rose" get pulled over by the cop, "Rose" insists that "Chris" doesn't have to show his id. Showing that she is a strong woman standing up for her man against blatant racism. However on second viewing, she is only defending "Chris" because she doesn't want any record of both of them together when he eventually gets reported missing. Soooo Good!!

There are big hints at racism/stereotype in the film that is portrayed and handled so perfectly , for example when the party is going an "Chris" is going round making small talk with people. At first viewing they all just seem a bit weird but actually there are shaping him up for the auction. The final part I really like that cuts so deep is how "Chris" frees himself from the basement, by stuffing seat fluff in his ears. However Im pretty sure I heard Jordan Peele in an interview say that it was actually referencing a black man picking cotton out of the seat to free himself............when I head that my jaw dropped! So unbelievably good !!

Overall this film is 85% out of 100 or 8.5 out of 10 its a really good film that should appeal to everyone, even if you are not a horror fan you should 100% check this out you won't regret it. For me it was the biggest surprise of 2017 because I'm not horror fan myself but I ending up loving the experience. If I was going to give it any negatives I'd say that the pacing here and there is a little off and film does drag a little. All in all I cant wait for what ever Jordan Peele does next!

title: Decent
review: Although this movie was entertaining it was very confusing. I didn't get the theme this movie was trying to get across. If you ignore how little since this movie makes then it makes it an interesting horror movie. It is different from some of the other movies that I have seen through out my years. It wasn't what i was expecting and has a weird plot twist. But then again... what was the point?

title: This movie has it all.
review: Humor, suspense, wit; the premise is unique & the delivery is basically spotless. I watched this movie in an attempt to reconcile the two wasted hours I spent watching (Daniel Aronofsky's trainwreck) Mother! & afterwards, I felt totally vindicated. This film was riveting from start to finish. It delivers on every promise it makes, it keeps you guessing until the end, it's smart, it's satisfying... it's 10/10 easy.

title: Cerebral Thriller
review:
Before watching this, I read a lot of the reviews, including the ones that called this movie racist and it almost made me decide not to watch it. However, I enjoyed watching Daniel Kaluuya in Sicario and didn't want to pass up the opportunity to see him give another amazing performance. I'm glad I decided to ignore the detractors and watch this movie. It was one of the most intelligent thrillers I've seen in a long time. Jordan Peele's directing style reminded me a lot of Hitchcock in that the scares and thrills creep up on you and you feel something isn't quite right but you're not sure why. 
This movie is rife with intricate symbolism and I can see why a course was created and inspired by this movie. Being able to see the events unfold through the eyes of the Chris character was, at times, uncomfortable but also enlightening. Towards the end of the movie I was cheering him on as he gave the Armitage family their comeuppance. Do I believe this movie is racist against white people? Not at all. I believe it is using an exaggerated situation to describe how the writer/director feels or has felt through out his life. I think the ultimate demise of the Armitage family is symbolic of his triumphing over the "Sunken Place".
I also believe people want to take things at face value and not look below the surface or try to see things from someone else's perspective. If you do not go into this movie with an open mind, you will be cheating yourself out of what is arguably one of the best thrillers.

title: My expectations were probably way too high...
review: I was led to believe that it was worth watching and I was told that I should avoid spoiling myself at all costs so I didn't even watch the trailer... 5 minutes in and I already had a theory about how twisted the story will/could get... I was so wrong... By the time we got to the last 3-5 minutes I still got hopes that there will be a big twist some crazy ending, I had multiple theories about how the mom and the deer are somehow connected, that this is all a dream and just a way to cure his addiction or make him get over loosing his mother or whatever, something unexpected that I didn't notice... but no it was a straightforward "thriller" with barely any suspense, nothing scary, and nothing unexpected... The acting is the only thing that lifts it up to mediocre without some quite believable performances(though it's not that hard to make this setting creepy or awkward with okay acting) it would be quite below that... I'm really baffled how this got any other nomination from the academy than maybe best actor(and that is a big maybe) ...winning best screenplay? I would laugh if this weren't so sad... I was quite hopeful till the movie ended, but it was ultimately really disappointing.

title: Good performances let down by the rest of the film
review:
An excellent performance by Daniel Kaluuya really carries this film far beyond where it should be. Allison Williams also deserves a mention.

Unfortunately, the rest of the film doesn't live up their standards.

A distinctly average script and similar direction from Jordan Peele really scuppers the film, yet it has somehow garnered numerous award nominations and raked in a whole load of money from a tiny budget, so we'll definitely be hearing at lot more from Jordan Peele.

It's one of those films that managed to get word of mouth right, but in the future it won't be regarded as well as it is now.

Hopefully next time the budget will allow for a decent script doctor to whip it into shape.

title: Murky and unfocused in what it wants to say
review:
I finally managed to sit down and see the film that has had EVERYONE talking for over a year now...and now, I can speak my thoughts regarding it.

To preface, I adore Jordan Peele's work as a writer. If you have not yet seen Key & Peele, I demand you see it. Peele is an excellent comedy writer.

That said...I cannot, for the life of me, say that I see what others have raved about in this film.

Jordan Peele may be an excellent writer, but his direction is honestly lacking in this film. Many of these shots are framed more in-line with a television series, with lighting that looks like it's a comedy, not the horror/thriller it wants so badly to be. The 'scares' lack that staying power that keeps you on-edge. This is a fault in direction, and I honestly can give some leeway for that in that this is his first major film.

That said, his writing lacks the power it needs to send this film chugging along. The screenplay contains borrowed parts from a much better film ('Being John Malkovich'), and any of the points it aims to make regarding race relations and racial tensions, they're either points that have been made before or are too murky and lack that real 'pulp' to make a difference. There was something that Peele clearly wanted to say, but I feel like there wasn't enough clarity to truly deliver on it.

The performances were about as serviceable as any other Blumhouse horror film. They serve the story and the concept well, they invest you enough. I did not see what was so Oscar-worthy regarding Daniel Kaluuya's performance, but that's simply my viewpoint on it.

My biggest issues here, however, come with the aforementioned screenplay. It simply cannot decide WHAT it wants to be, and that's perhaps the greatest flaw this film has.

Does it want to be a horror film and taken seriously? Of course not. There's a scene where Jeffrey Dahmer and what he did with human heads is discussed in a sexual manner. Does this want to be a dark comedy? Hardly. There's not enough moments of levity beyond the main protagonist's friend to give us an idea of that tone. Does this film want to be a biting commentary on racism and current-day race politics?

Honestly, I can't even be sure there. Much of this film's commentary on race feels either done-before or unfocused. We only get concepts as deep as echoes of slavery and stereotype. Why not talk about the double-standards of race and race relations in this modern era? Why not talk about the alarming way culture will occasionally assure itself racism is 'over' and is no longer an issue in this day and age? There are just so many things a concept like this COULD have said, but I find myself reaching conclusions that I have already reached with past films, while Jordan Peele paints them as novel and new concepts in this film.

My issues extend to further things beyond just the execution of its commentary, however. There are plot holes within the film that I simply cannot excuse. I cannot divulge them here, but there were points where I had to verbally ask myself 'Wait, how...?', which does not bode well for a film. To go further, the screenplay finds itself in the land of conventions by its 3rd act, and a few questionable choices by its characters lead me to ponder the film world's logic.

All of this said...I appreciated that a film like this could be made in the first place. Its concept, borrowed as it is, is a WEIRD one, and I appreciate that it isn't a tired, worn-out film plot that I have seen thousands of times before. I'd rather have a film I've seen once before than a hundred.

To further move off that, while I did critique the cinematography, there are some beautiful gems of shots tucked-away in this film. Particularly in the 3rd act, when the lighting and sets turn dream-like and we get a world that looks far more interesting than its first two-thirds.

In the end, after months and months of hearing about this film and keeping myself fresh and ready to give it a run...in the end, it's really nothing I haven't seen before. There are better horror films. There are better dark comedies. There are better films tackling race. There are better-directed films. There are better-acted films.

Aside from its tense soundtrack, a few beautiful shots, and a sense of originality that is lacking in today's mainstream film world, I really cannot say I am with the hype train on this one, but I absolutely recommend you check it out. Maybe you'll see something I missed~

title: Good fun, but not Oscar material
review:
"Get out" is a well-crafted little thriller, with just the right balance between dead pan humor, poking fun at stereotypes - like "blacks stalking whites in bad neighborhoods" being reversed, "TSA is less competent than police" being reversed, and so forth. There's even some mild horror action at the end.

The premise is well-designed, as black dude Chris and his all-too-perfect white girlfriend meet her mom and dad, who show a little too much concern for his health. Little does Chris know that among the party guests at the parent's secluded estate, the one old blind guy who seems like an OK chap has designs on Chris' body and eyes. Chris is increasingly clued in that something very fishy is going on, with mom hypnotizing him, dad a weird brain surgeon, and the black groundskeeper, the black maid and a black party guest behaving oddly like white folks.

Never mind that Chris' buddy, who works for the TSA, is smelling the roses when they chat on the cell phone, and tells Chris to get the hell outta there. It's too late when Chris finally discovers a shoebox with photos of his girlfriend and a string of previous black suitors, all gone missing.

From this point on, the horror chapter of the script ensues, and it dips into the usual pitfalls of horror flicks, making "Get Out" not even remotely worthy of Oscar consideration. Why for example would Chris' girlfriend string him along when he finally tries to "Get Out," instead of mom just immediately invoking her well-established hypnotic control over him? They needlessly endanger the good health of Chris' body, and they do want it in good health! But the scriptwriters wanted the "nice character who seemingly supports the hero and goes 'bad' on him last" horror clichÃ© in the film. There are many such class-B horror movie artifices towards the end.

The films lacks the cleverness of Hitchcock thrillers, the outrageousness of a Peter Jackson horror flick, but it has humor, and is well-staged to the bitter end, despite being fairly predictable about two-thirds of the way through. Thus it deserves a good chuckle, and provides a satisfying one-time view with some good surprises - That's worth a 7/10.

title: I've seen it twice and "like it" but never believe in the premise
review:
(SPOILERS)

It's a very clever script, very tight with some great foreshadowing and humor but after watching it twice, here's what I don't understand: Why would ANY wealthy white person want to be Black? It makes zero sense to me. They talk about wanting to be "cool" and "strong" and "Black is in" (really?) but we know the horrific prejudice that remains. I could see black people wanting to be white to enjoy White Privilege, but whites wanting to be black? It just never made any sense to me. Still, a fine film.

title: The endings of get out
review: Get out is a movie how is produced with really les money and for that is it a real good film. I like the movie it's an excited movie with really good actors and it have a lot of plot twists in it the best thing at the movie is that the reinsure created tow endings and I am big supporter of tow endings because the spectator can choose which ending he prefers and I'm definitely a big fan from the second ending when the police is Cumming and he have to go into prison. That is the realistic ending but also the sad one but I think that is exactly the theme what the movie wanted to show us, that racism is still a there and still a big problem in the world

title: Rushed Resolution:could have been way better
review: For a new director, Peele debuts well, very well actually. I loved the acting, the lead, David Kaluuya did it for me. Allison Williams also did good. I mean the theme of the movie was quiet clear from the start and so you would follow in hopes of a rewarding resolution. My major setback was the finishing, i recall checking time left on the movie around when Chris wanted to leave because he had found them out, and i knew they where going to have to rush the ending. I was left unsatisfied to say the least. I enjoyed the fact that Peele wrapped what could have been a gruesome horror movie into something more subtle like a white girl taking home a black boyfriend but expected a more involving intense finishing. i wanted my WHY answered, why they did what they did, what was the essence to them, what was the essence even to us. For some reason i wanted to know they (white family) had regretted their actions but of course we are not given that luxury since Chris murders them all before any of them could share a dialogue. And where did Lil Rel come from, all of a sudden he gets a police car and appears just when all has ended, come on, too safe and too cliche for me.

title: Disappointing
review: I find it difficult to believe this film was nominated for two Golden Globe awards. It reminds me more of a second rate seventies horror flick than an award eligible film. The plot is distressingly predictable. The acting is better than in a second rate seventies horror flick, but that is the only highlight of this film. This film is not worth watching.

title: Although well directed and acted, that doesn't matter if the
review:
Reveal isn't solid. And it wasn't.

(I should preface this with me being a white man in his 50, albeit a ultra liberal.)

And with this, it's all about just waiting around for the reveal. It was paced and acted well but pedestrian in the writing and character development.

And why? Why all this front-end crap for something that could have been done with a simple kidnapping? It was just an extended creepfest without the slightest sense of purpose in the end (except the very vague "auction").

You know. A kidnapping. Like they had at the beginning of the film. Why was it so important to string out the middle act if that was a clear and very easy option?

And in that, it made no sense. Not even economic sense. If there were so many potential "customers" at the party, why not just kidnap and make more money?

Why would the daughter Rose go through what was apparently four months of a relationship with the lead Chris just to have him as fodder for the psychotic white doctor and, conveniently, the psychotic family members? Kidnapping would have done the same. It was the height of sociopathic for the whole family being that she was constantly having sex with men she didn't care for.

And the other glaring omission. Why him? He was a good guy, sure. But like the other example of someone taking over a young man's body, the character of the person being invaded made no difference. It was never defined (nor attempted) why Chris was "special." And if it did, why would anyone choose to take over the body of a smoker?

Additionally, the mechanics of Rose having all these relationships would call for her to have contact with men that lived a safe distance from each other to avoid detection. Thus, more reason to just kidnap.

The element of social media would greatly increase leaving evidence behind in the form of photos of the men with Rose.

I finally realized that the day party to observe Chris was an auction for his body. Not like it could have been more vague. But even still the whole procedure was about transferring conscious and nothing about the character of the victim. Even the desire to have Chris' "eyes" made no sense as his eyes would not have given the recipient any creative advantage. Just rhetoric that sounded good.

It was about youth and vitality, which played into the fears of the perspective black audience, but I didn't buy that old whites would want to be transferred into such (without explanation that a film did not have latitude for). There were too many societal and personal blocks to white people consistently wanting to take over the bodies of blacks.

Grandma's and grampa's "act" was vastly played up as a cheap device to create suspicion and likely bore no relevance to the characters displayed in the "holding cell" video. The one instance we saw grampa in the video in the end was no explanation of their erratic behavior. Quite the opposite.

Chris' cell phone cut out when talking with his best friend. Was suggested that it was just the battery, but nothing suggested the battery was low.

And the elements of the finale were just plain dumb:

So Chris' attention is unavoidably directed toward a small closet with the door open. He HAD TO LOOK INSIDE! (Suggesting that it was left there to be found.) In it, there is a red box with all the photos of the other black men that Rose had lured to their demise. Looked great but...why was it there other than to quickly clarify a story element? None. Absolutely none.

I don't think you could hook up video to such an old television in the "holding cell."

The cotton in the ears was clever but why did he remove such other than to clarify the cotton was there? That's to say they didn't have continual video surveillance (although with the intercom that was stated), being that they started the videos when Chris woke up.

The operating room was the most unsanitary one in recent film memory. A box full of medical knives in a red felt-lined box looks good, but hardly realistic.

What was the procedure? Was there a device in the white patient's head that collected the conscious, which then was transferred into the black person's brain? Very vague and never defined. Not even cursory.

Seems very premature for Chris to kill the father other than the opportunity of violence.

Despite the many deleted scenes on the DVD extras, they never explained how the best friend found Chris. But probably something very simple related to his cell phone that the "bad guys" didn't think about.

And what was made of Chris' smoking? Zero. Zilch.

But in the end, they did extremely well vs. the budget, which negates anything I have to say. But for me it failed creatively and analytically in the execution.

title: First 2/3 interesting; last 1/3 stupid cliche trash
review: This movie kept you going with intrigue as to what was up exactly -- clearly something beyond merely a black boyfriend visiting white family. The main actor was very good, and it is unfortunate he's found himself in this movie that then resolves its mystery by turning into a cheap, error-filled slasher-type film. Errors such as -- when Chris (star) dispenses with attacking brother by smashing his skull so that brother immediately bleeds out profusely from the head on the floor, guess what? Brother soon after -- surprise! -- attacks him again, with no sign of blood or injury. Cheap. The whole operating room scene really made little to no sense, just added some creepiness (father didn't even stay sterile) and the whole film degenerated so entirely into a feeble, predictable horror attempt that I had to force myself to finish the last third because it was all so predictable and gruesome and boring. Would have liked to have seen a more thought-out resolution to this peculiar initial set-up, but screenplay lets you down entirely (unless you like seeing decent films degenerate into stupid slasher type films -- in which case, enjoy!)

title: The Claustrophobia of Racism
review:
"Get Out" isn't a horror film. It's a dark fable about how racism hypnotizes its victims in order to lobotomize them, in a white-is-right world so claustrophobic, you'll start breathing as heavily as Daniela Kaluuya ("Chris Washington").

While this is not a good film for any reason a film is generally considered "good," it's unforgettable for conveying the claustrophobia and terror black people experience when faced with powerful rich white people.

I don't believe but can't say for sure that Jordan Peele intended this as an indictment of the white race. Whether or no, "Get Out" is unforgettable for showing the helplessness to be dealt with in the U.S. if you are guilty of Living While Black.

Daniel Kaluuya's acting is Oscar-worthy. So is LilRel Howerey ("Rod" the TSA guy). The white cast is noteworthy only for Caleb Landry Jones (the brother, Jeremy). Catherine Keener and Bradley Whitford may have been wooden by design; I don't know, but the degree of woodenness hurts and doesn't help the film.

"Get Out" is not a good film for any reason other than understanding the terror of racism--but that seems more than reason to see it.

title: I have a hard time buying it.
review:
Don't get me wrong. I think this movie is good, but when some people in a movie ha some kind of secret scheme I always get stuck thinking of it a lot and I cant see them doing this scheme a lot and get away with it.

They seem to take the victims to the same house and have the same names. I cant see the police and family not find them with all the strange disappearances with Rose, which seems to be around the same area. There must be a lot of evidence. For example mobilphones or friends and family knowing that they are going away. You could of course argue that no one has disappeared and they can just say that they have chosen to be where they are. But their shift in personality I think family or others would think that something is wrong.

title: Not "the best ever" as I was told...
review:
If it wasn't for such trivial but obvious flaws I'd rate it a bit better, such as: mobile phone readily available (at the very end, as he was escaping)... oh my God, how could the director/ author overlook such detail???? There were ton of other misses, but i won't even bother, as it will be a waste of my time.

If you like something light and entertaining and plenty of free time, it's OK to give it ago, though don't keep your expectations too high, very predictable, from the very beginning, when she: "wouldn't let anyone mess with her boyfriend" by refusing to show his ID to the cop - i already knew what the end would be like...

title: I listen a lot and good of this movie, but I do not see it in it
review:
It is a film that takes advantage of something that is very fashionable today, the cinema that speaks of racism, to make a horror film. Of course, I do not see terror at any time, but I do not see terror, comedy, or drama, it's a mixture that does not know where it's going.

Sometimes it's even too obvious, almost ridiculous, when blacks are all strangers.

I did not get long, but the second part of the movie is completely amazing. I do not think Charles Bronson would have done it.

We can say that the actors are fine, yes, but they are not great.

What has disappointed me most is that I was expecting a horror movie, and I have not seen that even so. It's difficult to provoke fear, but I think this movie does not even try. While it is true that you see it and do not want to remove it to see how it ends, yes, the end is disappointing.

Photography, when they are outdoors, I do not like anything. Yes, it's day, but it's not a comedy. It does not support suspense, nor terror. In the interiors may be fine, but not good at all.

The direction, although it does not bore, but it does not manage to intrigue, nor to provoke fear, nor suspense. It even has ugly and bad compound plans.

You can see it but do not expect what is being said about it

title: Interesting
review:
Get Out's is not scary at all, however, has a unique story and dramatic scenes. Though there is too much emphasis on racism and slavery, the movie's flow and good performance of Daniel K. is able to create its own atmosphere that takes you in and increases your curiosity.

I can recommend you to watch this movie with mystery and dramatic actions. It's probable that you may like it more than I did.

title: Modern Noir
review: Although the acting wasn't that good. But it's specify as suspense, mystery, Theiler just like noir movie should be. only disappointment is it has a happy ending. Also it's not horror movie, that i am glad. The can reach Hitchcock's level of noir style. The direction is pretty good. In the end, I think they over did it. "GET OUT" don't justify the the title. Overall the movie was pretty Intense.

title: goof 2
review: Whilst being driven through country roads at !0:20 a creature hit the front of the car at windscreen level but right side mirror broke and blood on the headlight. Thought that maybe windshield might have least been cracked and maybe bonnet ( hood ) damaged since it was hit by a DEER at wind shield height. Still, it is good to see a film from the " Land of the FREE " which pitifully shows that the discrimination is so profound, but that shows honesty in the film itself.

title: Get Out with 6 or 7 stars out of 10
review:
SPOILER!

Half of the movie reminds me of The Skeleton Key (2005) and it's nothing new on this level. Second part of the movie is setting the plot so we start to realize what's is going on.

If it would'n be for a simple well known plot, the movie is quite enjoyable. Some other elements are new and interesting, directing is good. Some moments are silly and goofy but mostly the movie is nice.

Final thought: The movie is watchable and OK, but I fear that the most of us will see it just once.

title: Racist, although original and thrilling
review:
As with horror movies jump-scares are bound to happen, and it does in this movie, but it's mostly subtle and isn't forced.

I felt that the climax unfolding is rushed, but the buildup is done great, which makes to a pretty thrilling experience, but a bit of a disappointing resolve.

The main idea is original, never seen anything like it, a mix of societal phenomena and horror; clever.

Which brings me to my main problem with the movie: I care about representation and with the subtle ways this movie presents how people can be racist indirectly, is great, but it's blown way out of proportion. I thought this was to add to the fact that the main villains of this horror movie are crazy, which is fair, but every single one of them. Every single one, is racist to the protagonist, which is a racist representation of white people in of itself. While I know there is only one exception, the crazy guy that is surely not racist but just want the eyes; he is still.. crazy.

Even the only Asian character in the movie is guilty by association, is he after the protagonist as well?

I wonder how people in interracial relationships feel now.

title: Very well made and acted, though quite predictable.
review:
I heard a lot about this movie, it being very different and surprising. I, personally, did not find any of these qualities to the extent that others are praising it for.

As written in the title, it's a well made movie with quality acting and natural dialog which sets it apart from the rest of the cliché-ridden horror movies, but the plot, to me, held very little to no surprises.

As soon as I saw the black servants of the house acting weird and then learning that the mother can hypnotize people with such ease, the dots were connected and it became obvious that they have done something to them and are also planning to do something to Chris too.

One of the main elements of the plot, the fact that the family was stealing black people's bodies and transplanting their brains, although not obvious from the get go, had almost no impact, simply because it was already apparent that the family were involved in some kind of wrongdoing. It could've been about black magic, or organ harvesting, etc. and it would've still ended up pretty much the same with the same effect.

Near the end of the movie, I actually expected a plot twist of some kind, perhaps Chris imagining all this, or at least imagining his escape, or even more radical, revealing that the black servants were actually the villains and controlling the family, but none came.

Good movie but just above average. Worth a watch.

title: OK movie
review: Personally i think the whole racial think did not have a reason to be in this movie cause for me it seems by trying giving the we are all the same people actually focuses on the differences of the racial culture... In general "Skeleton key" did better the same general plot but it was an OK movie for me with great imagery all in all I am glad I saw it

title: Good, but overrated
review:
I watched "Get Out" with extremely high expectations. I really wanted to love this movie, unfortunately it did not happen. Maybe it was the average cinematography, or the sometimes enjoyable, sometimes over the top sidekick, maybe it was the Microsoft participation that looked like sponsorship, maybe I should've stayed after the credits.

Although I liked the speech it portrays throughout the film and is, in general terms, and original premise, I do feel like the film relies too much on the music to create the tension and set the tone, and that's a major inconvenient, at least for my personal taste.

Get out is a good film, but does exhibit some flaws i was not warned about by the critics.

title: Not bad, though a bit overrated
review: With so many critics giving this movie great reviews, I knew I had to eventually give it a look for myself. Though after watching it, I am not sure why it got as much fuss as it did. Don't get me wrong, I am glad I watched it, since it does have some genuine merit. Writer and director Jordan Peele does manage to capture the feeling of racial tensions in America quite well; while people may appear to be accepting, there is often still some uneasiness. He also gets good performances out of the no-name cast and makes the movie look good despite a pittance of a budget. As for horror scares and tension, there are also some effective stabs in this area. However, you'll have to wait a long time for the central character to really find himself in trouble. At 104 minutes in length, the movie is somewhat too long and stretched out. While the movie never gets to be boring, there's a significant amount of footage that could have been eliminated, which would have speeded up the pace significantly. Yes, watch the movie, but wait until you are in a more patient mood.

title: Dirty topic meets clean filmmaking
review: GET OUT manages to create a clean story line which works on at least three layers at the same time: The manifest, the obvious layer on the surface allowing you to get the what the "-effect just before the final act when the latent layer, the what-they-were-really-thinking-layer, gets revealed. And I think it's quite clear that their is a third, thematic layer, dealing with how deep racism sticks within the - what? soul? cultural memory? genetic code? - of these people. And it works as a cinematic experience: it's shocking, it's funny, it's ugly, there is suspense, there are well composed, symbolic pictures, clean again, with no grain and with a well figured out, mostly warm color concept. Still I wasn't very exited when I left the theater and I don't know really why. Was it the acting? No, especially Daniel Kaluuya did an impressing job. The lack of originality? No, there are references to other movies, of course, images one to one resembling the bubble with the Tree of life in space in THE FOUNTAIN, only here it sinks down, while there it's raising, but the idea to show racism as horror within the codes of the genre is actually quite unique and quite brilliant. Is it because it all nevertheless feels too constructed to touch my feelings? Yeah, I think that might be the point. The topic is dirty, but the filmmaking is just way too clean.

title: Russel Wilson - hybrid.
review:
Get Out is at its best when it is busy tightening the screws around its audience, who are shifting uncomfortably around in their seats as black protagonist Chris Washington is assaulted by a barrage of micro-aggressions from his girlfriend's family. She's Allison Williams as the courageous Rose Armitage, treading through racial boundaries and taboos to find love. She also constantly finds herself apologising for the way in her parents and sibling welcome Chris into the family, fetishising his race and proudly brandishing their token Armitage minority like a shiny black trophy. Rose isn't just looking past skin colour, but actively calling out these incidents on behalf of her boyfriend, defending his man while flashing a smile so dazzling she must have stepped straight out of a Colgate commercial. A little too perfect.

Scarier than the expected spikes in the soundtrack and the blank smiles of the black servants are the trenches that Chris must navigate in his introduction to the Armitage estate. Peele closely tiptoes the line between satire and reality here, accompanied by the sheer ease in which Daniel Kaluuya slips into a role that he seems to have lived his entire lifetime; expected sighs, a narrowing of the eyes at every other inappropriate comment, a shake of the head after the moment is briefly disarmed. This constant unease and discomfort is more alarming than the film's clichéd 'gotcha' horror scares, especially coming from the well-worn performances of Whitford and Keener, who do a better job of hiding their sinister intentions than the help, and a ratty brother who looks Chris up and down like a specimen in a lab. Even when these are obviously signposted ("I would have voted for Obama for a third term if I could") they retain their sharpness like a gut punch; it's racial prejudice rebranded as simpering patronisation.

The villains of the film aren't right-wing Nazis or hardcore racists, but white liberals who think themselves gracious by welcoming minorities into their household, patting them on the back and calling them "my man" once too many times. Peele is taking aim at a uniquely intriguing clique here, painting a sleek, pristine portrait of a dreamy, post-racial America that is conveniently situated within an upper-class mansion, tucked away in some quiet, idyllic forest. His intentions are fascinating and sobering all at once, but the overall message is wrapped up in a rather clumsy, obvious metaphor that uses tired horror conventions to ramp up anxiety levels. Peele came from skit comedy, and it shows; the film's premise could be one of his older five minute sketches, of white liberals so obsessed with overcompensating for the past that they are literally snatching up the bodies of these fine black specimens and immortalising themselves within them. They worship their newfound vessel, parade his physical talents for all to see, slap the cigarette out of his hands, and arrive in an ominous procession to bid for the rights to claim him.

While Peele establishes a valid target in the first half of the movie, the second veers into a sort of cheap, exploitation territory where we are actively cheering for each posh cult member Chris offs in his bid for freedom. It grafts deeper dichotomies through scenes such as where the white-robed Rose sips milk and googles (sorry, bings) top NCCA prospects with a blank stare, or through the character of Rod, the polar opposite of the genteel black boyfriend in Chris, a loudmouth caricature of a ghetto TSA agent who does the digging into the Armitage conspiracy (he's no longer the target of 'random' spot checks, but rather on the other side of them, exposing lies). These characterisations are low-hanging fruit disguised as complex attitudes, and although we applaud as Rod steps out of the car to save the day, what do we really learn from this? That his concerns were correct all along, and that black men should stay away from dating white women altogether? There's more alarming authenticity packed into that split second of dread that Chris and the entire audience register as the sirens roll up to the scene of a black man strangling a white woman than there is in the rest of the film. To actually have a cop (or, if he was really subtle about it, the same cop from the deer encounter) emerge from the car and clasp Chris in handcuffs would be bludgeoning the point in, yet prove a whole lot more. But Rod takes us back to square one. His fears have been validated.

title: Damn Freaky
review: This movie was bizarre, freaky, weird, twisted, insane. The first hour was great but after that it went downhill and left you puzzled and dumbstruck - thinking what on earth is going on? The acting and filming was good. The music was weird. Is it a Horror, Thriller and/or Comedy? The adjectives in the first line are suiting.

title: A horror theme to tie it all together
review:
It was well done, well shot, had all the elements of a slightly entertaining formatted Hollywood movie. There was some suspense. I guess there were some quasi ethnic themes and the horror bit was necessary to tie it all together. Acting was good.

Mainly I'm using IMDb to keep track of my own thoughts so that in my declining prime I forget a few past movies nights and accidentally rewatch some uninspiring movies. Wouldn't watch this a second time although had an entertained 90 minutes in the theatre. They all laughed at the wrong bits, I think a lot of people thought it was a comedy because of Peele the director.

title: Do The Rock Steady
review:
Get Out is a satirical horror film. In some ways it reminded me of the remake of The Stepford Wives.

Daniel Kaluuya plays Chris Washington who is on a weekend visit to the parents of his white girlfriend Rose. (Allison Williams). Her father is a neurosurgeon and her mother is a hypnotherapist.

The family come across as an inclusive affluent liberal family who welcome this young black man. Chris however feels perturbed, even suspicious especially as he believes he has been hypnotised by Rose's mother.

At a family garden party Chris finds that their friends and neighbours although welcoming also take an unusual interest in him. Something is not right and even Rose might be complicit to whatever is going on.

The film directed by Jordan Peele is actually very slow to get going but does leave you intrigued as to how it will all turn out, even hinting that what is going on might all be in Chris's mind. British actor Daniel Kaluuya has a wide eyed look of a lamb being led to slaughter. Comic relief is provided by his best buddy Rod, a TSA agent who finds incidents of young black men who have disappeared and forms a bizarre theory.

Like a lot of horror films, much of it in retrospect does not make too much sense.

title: A skeptical view of GET OUT
review: The second I walked out of the theater, i was certain of one thing. Get out is a very modern and unusual Horror movie which worths its ticket. With a great,dark atmosphere and some really interesting and thrilling interpretation. HOWEVER. I firmly see a great disadvantage that prevents our movie from being truly remarkable, and that is the final outcome.Although the movie build a GREAT stressing-in a good way- and thrilling atmosphere blessed with nice comic relieves, as the movie goes on and the excpectations rise, the fall from grace is dramatic, as the stress transform to laughter at certain moments and makes the final scenes look rather funny than thrilling. However, i recommend the film and acknowledge that it plays with the viewer's psychology in an interesting way,despite the mediocre end and purpose.Furthermore that is the opinion of a person who looks twice as he returns home due to some scenes.....

title: What, no chainsaw?
review: In a thriller that was inspired by horror movies that Jordan Peele has viewed over the course of his lifetime, there are a number of classic/cliché horror genre references - by design (Jordan Peele stated as much in interviews). One such allusion is the man with the ax - which he uses to split firewood. I thought it would've been an interesting scene for the same groundskeeper to come up unseen behind the protagonist, Chris, as he is walking silently through the woods; turn on the chainsaw, thereby startling Chris and the audience; then casually mention, as he cuts a dead tree into pieces that he will later "process" by splitting it into firewood, something like, "With a little effort and know-how, this decrepit old thing can be repurposed and made useful".
